column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=The inventors have determined whether sentrin-1 could associate with and covalently modify PML.
#Text=For this purpose, HA-epitope tagged PML (HA-PML) was expressed in COS cells and total cell lysates were analyzed by Western blotting, as previously described (Examples 5 7).
#Text=Three different antibodies were employed in this analysis.
#Text=As shown in FIG. 11A, a mouse anti-PML monoclonal antibody detected the 70 kDa PML (arrowhead) and a 90 kDa band (lane 2).
#Text=A rabbit anti-PML antiserum detected both the 70 kDa and 90 kDa band (lane 4).
#Text=There is also a weak higher molecular weight band in the lysate and several lower molecular weight bands, which are most likely degradation products of PML (lane 4).
#Text=A highly sensitive anti-HA monoclonal antibody detected several bands higher than 70 kDa (lane 6).

#Text=Since the predicted molecular weight of PML is only 70 kDa, the presence of these higher molecular weight bands suggest that PML could either migrate aberrantly or could be modified by other molecules, such as sentrin-1 or ubiquitin.
#Text=Next, an immunoprecipitation study was performed with COS cell lysates expressing HA-PML, as previously described (Examples 5 7) (FIG. 11B).
#Text=Two different anti-HA monoclonal antibodies were employed in this study to detect HA-PML and its derivatives.
#Text=The total cell lysates of the transfected COS cells contained the 70 kDa unmodified HA-PML and a series of higher molecular weight bands (lane 2).
#Text=As shown in lane 4, anti-FADD antiserum (Kamitani et al., 1997c) did not precipitate any proteins from the lysate.
#Text=In contrast, immunoprecipitation with anti-sentrin-1 antiserum (Kamitani et al., 1997a) precipitated two proteins that were approximately 70 and 90 kDa (lane 6).
#Text=These results suggest that HA-PML could be modified by sentrin-1.
#Text=However, the molecular weight of the precipitate does not match the modification pattern seen in FIG. 11A.
#Text=This is most likely due to protein degradation or de-sentrinization during immunoprecipitation.
#Text=To circumvent this problem, a different system was employed, as described in the inventors' recent report demonstrating the conjugation of sentrin-1 to RanGAP1.
#Text=Here, PML was tagged with RH epitope (RGSHHHHHH) (SEQ ID NO:7) at the C-terminus and expressed in COS cells.
#Text=Transfected cells were lysed with 6 M Guanidine HCl to denature proteins in the lysate and to prevent any non-specific proteolysis or de-sentrinization.
#Text=RH-tagged PML (PML-RH) was then precipitated with nickel-charged beads and was immunoblotted with either anti-sentrin-1 antiserum or with anti-RH monoclonal antibody.
#Text=As shown in FIG. 11C, 3 distinct bands were identified in the anti-sentrin-1 and anti-RH lanes (lanes 2, 4).
#Text=As a control, HA-PML could not be precipitated by nickel-charged beads and could not be detected with either anti-sentrin-1 antiserum or anti-RH antibody (lanes 1, 3).
#Text=These studies suggest that PML is covalently modified by sentrin-1 at multiple sites.

#Text=The inventors do not favor the possibility of modification at the single site by sentrin-1 multimers because sentrin-1 does not contain the conserved Lys48 equivalent required for multimer formation (Hershko and Ciechanover, 1992) (see FIG. 12).
#Text=This notion is further supported by the observation that RanGAP1 is modified by a single molecule of sentrin-1/GMP1/SUMO1 (Kamitani et al., 1997b; Mahajan et al., 1997; Matunis et al., 1996).
#Text=Sentrin-1 belongs to a family of ubiquitin-like proteins (see FIG. 12).
#Text=Sentrin homologues have been reported from A. thaliana to H. sapiens, suggesting that sentrin-1 is an evolutionary conserved protein that may perform unique functions in cellular metabolism.
#Text=Further analysis of the database revealed two additional human cDNA sequences that are highly homologous to sentrin-1 (Mannen et al., 1996; Lapenta et al., 1997).
#Text=This is of interest because there is only one sentrin homologue reported for all of the non-mammalian genera and species.

#Text=While original publications by the inventors referred to the protein as "sentrin", the inventors have now renamed the protein "sentrin-1" and the other two sequences as sentrin-2 (T08096/X99585) and sentrin-3 (X99584).
#Text=It is not known whether sentrin-2 or sentrin-3 could form covalent conjugates with other proteins.
#Text=Since sentrin-1 could covalently modify PML, it is of interest to determine whether sentrin-2 or sentrin-3 could also be used as PML modifiers.
#Text=For this purpose, HA-tag was placed at the N-termini of sentrin-1, sentrin-2, and sentrin-3 and expressed in COS cells as previously described (Kamitani et al., 1997a).
#Text=RanGAP1 was used as a positive control because RanGAP1 is covalently modified by sentrin-1 or SUMO-1/GMP1 (Kamitani et al., 1997a; Mahajan et al., 1997; Matunis et al., 1996).
#Text=It is not known, however, whether RanGAP1 could be modified by sentrin-2 or sentrin-3.
#Text=HA-tagged sentrin family members were co-expressed with RH-RanGAP1 in COS cells.
#Text=Total cell lysates were incubated with nickel-charged beads to precipitate RH-RanGAP1 and its derivatives.
#Text=As shown in FIG. 13A, sentrin-1, sentrin-2, or sentrin-3 could covalently modify RanGAP1 (lane 4, 5, 6).
#Text=This is specific because neither Rad51 (lane 1), ubiquitin (lane 2), nor NEDD8 (lane 3) could modify RanGAP1.
#Text=The purified RH-RanGAP1 derivatives were also detected in a separate Western blot analysis utilizing anti-RH monoclonal antibody (lanes 7 12).
#Text=As shown, both the unmodified RanGAP1 and sentrinized RanGAP1 were detected in all samples.
#Text=It should be noted that p90 in lanes 7 9 was derived from RanGAP1 modified by native sentrin in COS cells.
#Text=This is further supported by the observation of a 90 kDa doublet in the HA-sentrin-1, 2, or 3 transfected sample (lanes 10 12).
#Text=The upper band of the doublet is most likely RanGAP1 modified by HA-sentrin and the lower band is most likely RanGAP1 modified by native sentrin (lanes 10 12).
#Text=It should be noted that a single 90 kDa band was observed in cells expressing HA-tagged sentrin-1 (lane 4 6), suggesting that RanGAP1 is modified by one sentrin-1 molecule.
#Text=These studies also provide the first evidence that RanGAP1 could be covalently modified by all sentrin family members.
#Text=This modification is highly specific because neither NEDD8 nor ubiquitin could form a covalent linkage with RanGAP1.
